title: 2.1: Emitter Shapes
summary: Explore various emitter shapes: cone, sphere, box, and more
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn about different emitter shapes available in the Node Particle Editor. Each shape creates particles from a different volume, giving you control over where particles spawn. We'll focus on ConeShapeBlock, which creates directional effects like fire or fountains, and understand its properties like radius, angle, radiusRange, and heightRange.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Use ConeShapeBlock to emit particles in a cone pattern
Connect a ParticleInputBlock to set the cone radius (base width of the cone)
Connect another ParticleInputBlock to set the cone angle (opening angle in radians)
Connect ParticleInputBlock to set radiusRange for random variation in radius
Connect ParticleInputBlock to set heightRange for random variation in height
Experiment with different radius and angle values to see how they affect particle distribution
Note: Other shapes like SphereShapeBlock, CylinderShapeBlock, and PointShapeBlock are also available

blocks.name: SphereShapeBlock

codeCopy: Different emitter shapes give you control over the spatial distribution of particles. SphereShapeBlock creates particles within a spherical volume, while BoxShapeBlock uses a rectangular volume. Each shape has specific properties like radius, height, or angle that control the emission area. The radiusRange property in SphereShapeBlock is particularly useful - it lets you control whether particles spawn only at the center (0) or throughout the entire volume (1).
objectives: Understand different emitter shapes and their properties
Learn how to control particle spawn distribution with radiusRange
Use directionRandomizer to control emission direction
Understand when to use each shape type (Point, Box, Sphere, Cone, Cylinder)
Configure shape properties like radius, angle, and height

commonMistakes.explanation: radiusRange controls where particles spawn within a shape. 0 means particles spawn only at the center, 1 means anywhere in the volume. Using wrong values creates unexpected distributions.
commonMistakes.solution: Use radiusRange = 0 for concentrated emission (center only), radiusRange = 1 for full volume emission. For sphere shapes, this is particularly important for controlling particle spread.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong shape for the desired effect
commonMistakes.explanation: Each shape has specific use cases. Using BoxShapeBlock for a fountain effect or ConeShapeBlock for uniform distribution won't give the desired result.
commonMistakes.solution: Use PointShapeBlock for concentrated effects, SphereShapeBlock for radial effects, ConeShapeBlock for directional effects (fire, fountains), BoxShapeBlock for rectangular areas, CylinderShapeBlock for cylindrical volumes.

commonMistakes.explanation: Shapes have properties like radius, angle, height that must be set correctly. Using default values or wrong types causes incorrect emission.
commonMistakes.solution: Always set shape properties explicitly. For ConeShapeBlock, set both radius and angle. For SphereShapeBlock, set radius and radiusRange. Check the shape's required properties in documentation.
